Lilies are a commercially significant cut flower worldwide due not only to their elegant shape but also to their appealing scent. Among
Lilium
varieties,
Lilium
‘Siberia’ is a cultivar that is prominent and highly favored by consumers due to its snowy white color and strong floral scent. Here, two terpene synthase genes ( LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 ) that are responsible for floral scent production in
Lilium
‘Siberia’ were cloned and functionally characterized. Recombinant LoTPS2 specifically catalyzed the formation of ( E , E )-α- farnesene from FPP. Recombinant LoTPS4 is a multiproduct enzyme that produces D-limonene and β- myrcene as major volatile compounds and β- phellandrene, (+)-4-carene and 3-carene as minor products from GPP. Furthermore, LoTPS4 generates trans-α- bergamotene as a major product and di-epi-α- cedrene, α- cubebene and ( E )-β- farnesene as minor compounds from FPP. Subcellular localization analysis using GFP fusion constructs revealed that LoTPS2 was localized in the cytosol, whereas LoTPS4 was localized in plastids. Real-time PCR analysis showed that LoTPS2 was highly expressed in the petals and sepals of the flower, while LoTPS4 was highly expressed in the filament of the flower. Moreover, mechanical wounding of flowers revealed that LoTPS2 showed a strong response to wounding via a rapid increase in its mRNA transcript level. Our results will assist scientists in exploring the molecular mechanisms of terpene biosynthesis in this species and will provide new insight into the biotechnological modification of the floral bouquet in
Lilium
.
Abstract

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
The genus
Lilium
includes very popular scented bulb flower species with high economic and ornamental value.
Lilium
holds a prominent position in the world's fresh cut flower market, and its members used as potted and common landscape flowers in gardens because of their variety of colors and beautiful shapes (
). Among the species in this genus,
Lilium
‘Siberia’ (Oriental hybrid) is a very popular and unique flower because of its pure snowy white color and the strong scent that it releases, and this variety is highly appreciated by consumers. Oriental hybrid lilies (
Lilium spp.
) are derived from interspecific hybridization among species of the section Archelirion , including
Lilium auratum
and
Lilium speciosum ( Yamagishi et al., 2018 )
. The majority of the fragrance produced in the
Lilium
‘Siberia’ is found in the sepals and petals, which are the key parts involved in floral scent emission (
). Moreover, the emission pattern of the floral bouquet typically matches the pollinator's activity, following a diurnal circadian rhythm (
;
).

Floral scent formation and regulation in this spectacular breed have been ignored thus far, and the mechanism of floral scent production has not been characterized. Here, we report two terpene synthase genes involved in floral fragrance formation in
Lilium
‘Siberia’. As
Lilium species
vary in their characteristics and ornamental traits, our results will facilitate the manipulation of terpene synthase genes to achieve floral scent formation in unscented or less scented
Lilium
breeds using genetic engineering and bioinformatics tools.

sec.title: 2.1. Phylogenetic analysis
2.2. Functional characterization of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4
sec.p:
To examine the enzymatic activity of LoTPS2 and LoTPS
4 in
vitro, the full-length coding regions of corresponding recombinant proteins were overexpressed in the pET30a vector using
Escherichia coli
Rosetta-gammi B ( DE 3) competent cells, and their activity was assayed with the potential substrates GPP, FPP, and GGPP. Incubation of the recombinant LoTPS2 protein with FPP resulted in the production of ( E , E )- α- farnesene, whereas no product was found when GPP and GGPP were used as substrates ( Fig. 2 ). Similarly, no product was found in the control (extracts of
E. coli
expressing the empty vector in the presence of FPP).

sec.title: 2.3. Expression analysis of the LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 genes
sec.p:
Quantitative real-time PCR was performed to determine the expression of the LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 genes in various
Lilium
‘Siberia’ organ tissues (root, bulb, stem, leaf, petal, sepal, stigma, anther and filament) ( Figs. 5 and 6 ). The highest expression of LoTPS2 was observed in the petals followed by the sepals, which are the key plant parts exhibiting the highest aroma levels, indicating their major involvement in floral scent formation ( Fig. 5a ). Furthermore, LoTPS2 showed lower expression in all other organs ( Fig. 5a ). In contrast, LoTPS4 showed the highest expression level in the filament, followed by the stigma, sepals and petals of the flower, ( Fig. 5b ).

The mRNA expression levels of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 were analyzed using blooming flowers from six different fragrance types of
Lilium
varieties. The results showed that LoTPS2 was most highly expressed in the strongly scented
Lilium
‘Siberia’, followed by ‘Acapulco’ and ‘Manissa’, which are moderately scented varieties; whereas its expression was lower in ‘Longiflorum’ ( Fig. 5c ). LoTPS4 was most highly expressed in ‘Acapulco’, followed by ‘Longiflorum’ and ‘Siberia’ ( Fig. 5d ).

To investigate the relative expression of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 , the flower development process was divided into five stages, designated D1 (flower bud), D2 (slightly open), D3 (half open), D4 (fully bloom), and D5 (flower senescence) ( Fig. 6 ). LoTPS2 showed the highest expression in full-bloom flowers, whereas lower expression was observed at the D3 and D5 stages, and its expression was almost undetectable at the D1 and D2 stages ( Fig. 7a ). However, LoTPS4 showed the highest expression at the D1 stage and lower expression at the D3 and D5 stages ( Fig. 7b ). To determine the expression patterns of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4, flower development was divided into two categories: from the bud stage to full-bloom stage and from the full-bloom stage to the three days later, to examine the circadian expression pattern at 8 h intervals. During flower development, there was no expression of the LoTPS2 mRNA transcript before 48 h, and the transcript level started to increase thereafter ( Fig. 7c ). In contrast, the mRNA transcript levels of LoTPS4 were highest at the bud stage and began to decline with the development of flowers, then increased again at the full-bloom stage ( Fig. 7d ). Over the course of a day/night cycle, LoTPS2 expression followed a strong diurnal rhythm, with peak expression levels in the morning (8:00), followed by the afternoon (16:00) and deep night (24:00) ( Fig. 8a ). Similarly, the emission of ( E , E ) α- farnesene followed a diurnal circadian pattern, with the highest emission in the morning, followed by deep night and afternoon ( Fig. 8c ). Over the course of a day/night cycle, LoTPS4 showed random expression and did not follow any circadian pattern in its expression ( Fig. 8b ). D-limonene also showed a random emission pattern ( Fig. 8d ).

sec.title: 2.4. The expression of LoTPSs and emission of volatiles was induced by mechanical wounding
sec.p:
Previous research has indicated that terpene synthases (especially sesqui-TPSs and mono-TPSs) are involved in floral defense and airborne signaling under certain conditions. The results revealed that LoTPS2 showed a quick response to mechanical wounding in
Lilium
‘Siberia’, indicating its possible involvement in a defense reaction, signaling or attraction of pollinators. The mRNA transcript level of LoTPS2 started to increase after 1/5 h after wounding and peaked after 1 h (~2.6 fold–higher expression compared to the control) ( Fig. 9a ). At 1 h after wounding, the transcript levels began to decrease, then rapidly increased after 6 h (~2.4 fold-higher expressions) and declined thereafter. Similarly, the emission of ( E , E )-α- farnesene was undetectable before 2 h after wounding; however, its emission started increase after 4 h, and maximum emission was observed at 6 h, followed by 8 h, compared to the control ( Fig. 9b ). A similar response is observed in
Artemisia annua
and
Lotus japonicas
when they are subjected to wounding, resulting in higher transcript levels of TPSs (
;
). On the other hand, LoTPS4 did not show any response to wounding injury.

sec.title: 2.5. Subcellular localization of LoTPSs
sec.p:
The analysis of putative targeting sequences with different algorithms did not provide consistent predictions about the subcellular localization of the LoTPS2 protein, suggesting the presence of either a cytosolic/nuclear localization or chloroplast targeting sequence. To experimentally determine the subcellular localization of the LoTPS2 protein, transient expression of a green fluorescent protein (GFP) fusion protein was performed in
Arabidopsis
protoplasts. The full-length fragment beginning with the start codon of the LoTPS2 gene was introduced in frame into the vector p35 S-EGFP-1 and the construct transferred to
Arabidopsis
protoplasts, which were subsequently examined for transient GFP expression through confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM). The results showed that the fusion of LoTPS2 with GFP localized to the cytosol ( Fig. 10 ). In contrast, LoTPS4 was predicted to possess an N-terminal targeting peptide that is present in chloroplast monoterpene synthases but absent in cytosolic sesquiterpene synthases. To verify the actual subcellular localization of LoTPS4, constructs including the N-terminal 80 aa and the full-length peptide of LoTPS4 were generated as described above. The results showed that both the Nterminal and full-length peptides of LoTPS4 were located in plastids. The GFP constructs evidently supported the localization of LoTPS2 to the cytosol ( Fig. 10e–h ) and LoTPS4 to the plastids ( Fig. 10 i-p). Furthermore, HcTPS7 from
Hedychium coronarium
was observed as a positive control (
).

sec.title: 3.3. Functional characterization of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4
sec.p:
In conclusion, we functionally characterized two terpene synthases that are responsible for the production of floral scent in
Lilium
‘Siberia’ and localize to different compartments. LoTPS2 is a sesqui-TPS responsible for the biosynthesis of ( E , E )-α- farnesene exclusively from FPP, whereas LoTPS4 is a multiproduct terpene synthase that synthesizes both monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes from GPP and FPP, respectively. Our findings lay a molecular foundation for understanding the molecular mechanism underlying floral scent production.

sec.title: 4.1. Plant material and reagents
sec.p:
The lily cultivars (‘Siberia’, ‘Sorborne’ ‘Brunello’, ‘Acapulco’, ‘Longiflorum’, and ‘Manissa’) were grown in South China Agricultural University under natural light conditions.
Lilium
‘Siberia’ plants were bought from a wholesale
Lilium
‘Siberia’ cut flower market followed by immediate transfer to sterile water in a growth chamber (12-h light/12- h dark cycle). For the subcellular localization experiments,
Arabidopsis thaliana
ecotype Col-0 plants were grown in a growth chamber at 22 ̊ C under a 12-h light/12-h dark cycle.

sec.title: 4.2. Cloning of terpene synthase genes
sec.p:
Two terpene synthase genes ( LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 ) were selected from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ transcriptome data (data unpublished), based on the gene ontology (GO) annotation. Total RNA was extracted from full-bloom flowers using a plant RNA mini kit (Magen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The M-MuLV First cDNA Synthesis Kit (TaKaRa, Japan ), was used to synthesize first-strand cDNA according to the manufacturer's protocol. High-fidelity KOD-Plus DNA polymerase (TOYOBO) was used to clone the full-length genes according to the manufacturer's suggestions. The polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) conditions were as follows: 94 ̊ C for 2 min, followed by 40 cycles of 98 ̊ C for 10 s and 68 ̊ C for 1.5 min. The PCR product was extracted and purified from an agarose gel and purified using an Agarose Gel DNA Purification Kit (TaKaRa, Japan ) according to the manufacturer's instructions, followed by ligation into the TaKaRa pMD19-T vector (TaKaRa, Japan ) and sequencing.

4.5. Product identification
sec.p:
Standard assays were performed in a total volume of 1 ml containing assay buffer (20 mM MgCl 2 , 30 mM HEPES, pH 7.5, 5 mM DTT), 20 μM substrate (GPP, GGPP, and FPP) and the recombinant LoTPS proteins. Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS, with 50/30 μm divinylbenzene/ Carboxen) fiber (Supelco) for solid-phase microextraction was used to collect volatiles. The mixture was incubated at 30 ̊ C for 30 min followed by insertion of PDMS fiber into a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) system for volatile analysis. An Agilent 7890 A gas chromatography system coupled with an Agilent 5975 C mass spectrometry detector was used for GC-MS analyses as described previously (
). The products were recognized by comparing their mass spectra with the NIST08 mass spectrum library and known or authentic standards volatile compounds of
Lilium
‘Siberia’.

4.7. Quantitative RT-PCR analysis
sec.p:
Total RNA was extracted from different tissues (root, bulb, stem, leaf, sepal, petal, stigma, anther, and filament) and flower developmental stages named (D1, D2, D3, D4, and D5) ( Fig. 6a and b ) using HiPure plant RNA mini kit (Magen) following the manufacturer's instructions. One microgram of RNA was reverse transcribed by using the PrimeScript™ RT reagent Kit with genomic DNA Eraser (Takara) following the manufacturer's suggestions. Using Primer Premier 5.0 software, the reference genes were cloned from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ based on showing high conservation in plants. GAPDH was used as a reference gene for each sample. The sequence-specific primers for real-time PCR are listed in Supplementary Table 2. Gene-specific primers were used to amplify a 250 bp fragment in the 3′ end region of the sequence. Quantitative RT-PCR was performed in an ABI 7500 Fast Real-Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems, USA ) using iTaq™ Universal SYBRṜ Green Supermix (BIO-RAD, USA ) according to the manufacturer's protocol. qRT-PCR was performed in a total volume of 20 μl containing 10 μl iTaq™ Universal SYBRṜ Green Supermix, 2 μl cDNA obtained from different plant tissues, forward and reverse primer with following conditions; 95 ̊ C for 1 min followed by 40 cycles of 95 ̊ C for 15 s, 55 ̊ C for 30 s, 72 ̊ C for 30sec. The specificity of each primer pair was confirmed via melting and a standard curve. All experiments were repeated with 3 technical replicates, and the relative expression levels of target genes were calculated via the 2 −ΔΔCt method (
) and analyzed statistically.

sec.title: 4.8. Headspace analysis of floral volatiles and mechanical wounding
sec.p:
The development of flowers was divided into two stages: first from the bud stage to the full-bloom stage and from after the full-bloom stage to the senescence stage to check the circadian pattern of emissions. GC-MS analysis was performed at 8 h intervals from the bud stage to senescence, followed by freezing in liquid nitrogen and storage at −80 ̊ C for further analysis. A flower was placed in a 2000 ml beaker to which 2 μl decanoic acid was added as an internal standard, and the beaker was covered with an aluminum sheet for 30 min to trap the volatiles. Thereafter, PDMS fiber (Supelco) was inserted into the beaker for 30 min to adsorb the volatiles, followed by insertion into a GC-MS system (Agilent) with Agilent 7890 A GC and Agilent 5975 C MSD, equipped with an Agilent HP-5MS capillary column ( 30 m × 0.25 mm ) and helium gas was used as a carrier at a constant flow of 1 ml min −1 as described previously (
). The list of volatile compounds and their retention time emitted from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers are given in Supplementary Table 3. By comparing the retention time and mass spectra with the authentic standards, the volatiles were identified.

The wounding of flowers was performed with sterilized blades to a depth of 2–3 mm , followed by the collection of volatiles at 0, 1/2, 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 h after treatment. At each point, a control was also performed, followed by freezing in liquid nitrogen and storage at −80 ̊ C for further experiments.
